ipi-interface:interfaces.description: Top level container for interfaces, including configuration and state    data

interface.description: The list of named interfaces on the device.

name.description: The textual name of the interface. The value of this object should be the name of the interface as assigned by the local device and should be suitable for use in commands entered at the device's `console'. This might be a text name, such as `le0' or a simple port number, such as `1', depending on the interface naming syntax of the device. If several entries in the ifTable together represent a single interface as named by the device, then each will have the same value of name. Note that for an agent which responds to SNMP queries concerning an interface on some other (proxied) device, then the value of name for such an interface is the proxied device's local name for it. If there is no local name, or this object is otherwise not applicable, then this object contains a zero-length string.

config.description: Configurable items at the global, physical interface level

name.description: The textual name of the interface. The value of this object should be the name of the interface as assigned by the local device and should be suitable for use in commands entered at the device's `console'. This might be a text name, such as `le0' or a simple port number, such as `1', depending on the interface naming syntax of the device. If several entries in the ifTable together represent a single interface as named by the device, then each will have the same value of name . Note that for an agent which responds to SNMP queries concerning an interface on some other (proxied) device, then the value of name for such an interface is the proxied device's local name for it. If there is no local name, or this object is otherwise not applicable, then this object contains a zero-length string. To configure a subinterface, use the name of the base interface followed by a dot and a number in the range of 1-2000 (eg: xe1.1).

enable-switchport.description: This attribute is used to set the mode of the Hybrid Switch Router feature to switched only.All interfaces are configured routed by default

vrf-name.description: This attribute is used to associates an interface with a VRF

vr-name.description: This attribute is used to associates an interface with a VR

type.description: The type of the interface. When an interface entry is created, a server MAY initialize the type leaf with a valid value, e.g., if it is possible to derive the type from the name of the interface.

mtu.description: This attribute is used to set mtu value to interface.The size of the largest packet which can be sent/received on the interface, specified in octets. For interfaces that are used for transmitting network datagrams, this is the size of the largest network datagram that can be sent on the interface.

allow-first-frame.description: This Object is used to allow or drop first frame on L2 movement actions

dot1ad-ether-type.description: This attribute is used to configure the ethertype value for the interface in the format 0xhhhh. Currently supported values are 0x8100 (default) or 0x88a8 or 0x9100 or 0x9200.

domain-fastflush-config.description: Attribute to change domain fastflush value

protected-port.description: Attribute to change port protectedtype value

bridge-domain-forward.description: Attribute to change domain forward value

description.description: Use this attribute to set description for the interface

shutdown.description: Use this attribute to enable the selected interface. This leaf contains the configured, desired state of the interface. The testing(3) state indicates that no operational packets can be passed. When a managed system initializes, all interfaces start with ifAdminStatus in the down(2) state. As a result of either explicit management action or per configuration information retained by the managed system, ifAdminStatus is then changed to either the up(1) or testing(3) states (or remains in the down(2) state).

state.description: Operational state data at the global interface level

name.description: The textual name of the interface. The value of this object should be the name of the interface as assigned by the local device and should be suitable for use in commands entered at the device's `console'. This might be a text name, such as `le0' or a simple port number, such as `1', depending on the interface naming syntax of the device. If several entries in the ifTable together represent a single interface as named by the device, then each will have the same value of name . Note that for an agent which responds to SNMP queries concerning an interface on some other (proxied) device, then the value of name for such an interface is the proxied device's local name for it. If there is no local name, or this object is otherwise not applicable, then this object contains a zero-length string. To configure a subinterface, use the name of the base interface followed by a dot and a number in the range of 1-2000 (eg: xe1.1).

enable-switchport.description: This attribute is used to set the mode of the Hybrid Switch Router feature to switched only.All interfaces are configured routed by default

vrf-name.description: This attribute is used to associates an interface with a VRF

vr-name.description: This attribute is used to associates an interface with a VR

type.description: The type of the interface. When an interface entry is created, a server MAY initialize the type leaf with a valid value, e.g., if it is possible to derive the type from the name of the interface.

mtu.description: This attribute is used to set mtu value to interface.The size of the largest packet which can be sent/received on the interface, specified in octets. For interfaces that are used for transmitting network datagrams, this is the size of the largest network datagram that can be sent on the interface.

allow-first-frame.description: This Object is used to allow or drop first frame on L2 movement actions

dot1ad-ether-type.description: This attribute is used to configure the ethertype value for the interface in the format 0xhhhh. Currently supported values are 0x8100 (default) or 0x88a8 or 0x9100 or 0x9200.

domain-fastflush-config.description: Attribute to change domain fastflush value

protected-port.description: Attribute to change port protectedtype value

bridge-domain-forward.description: Attribute to change domain forward value

description.description: Use this attribute to set description for the interface

shutdown.description: Use this attribute to enable the selected interface. This leaf contains the configured, desired state of the interface. The testing(3) state indicates that no operational packets can be passed. When a managed system initializes, all interfaces start with ifAdminStatus in the down(2) state. As a result of either explicit management action or per configuration information retained by the managed system, ifAdminStatus is then changed to either the up(1) or testing(3) states (or remains in the down(2) state).

ifindex.description: System assigned number for each interface. A unique value, greater than zero, for each interface.It is recommended that values are assigned contiguously starting from 1.The value for each interface sub-layer must remain constant at least from one re-initialization of the entity's network management system to the next re-initialization.

admin-status.description: The desired state of the interface. It reflects the administrative state as set by enabling or disabling the interface.

oper-status.description: The current operational state of the interface. The testing(3) state indicates that no operational packets can be passed. If admin-status is down(2) then oper-status should be down(2). If admin-status is changed to up(1) then oper-status should change to up(1) if the interface is ready to transmit and receive network traffic; it should change to dormant(5) if the interface is waiting for external actions (such as a serial line waiting for an incoming connection); it should remain in the down(2) state if and only if there is a fault that prevents it from going to the up(1) state; it should remain in the notPresent(6) state if the interface has missing (typically, hardware) components.

last-change.description: The value of sysUpTime at the time the interface entered its current operational state.If the current state was entered prior to the last re-initialization of the local network management subsystem then this object contains a zero value

logical.description: When set to true, the interface is a logical interface which does not have an associated physical port or channel on the system

counters.description: A collection of interface-related statistics objects

in-octets.description: The total number of octets received on the interface, including framing characters. Discontinuities in the value of this counter can occur at re-initialization of the management system, and at other times as indicated by the value of 'last-clear'.

in-pkts.description: The total number of packets received on the interface, including all unicast, multicast, broadcast and bad packets etc.

in-unicast-pkts.description: The number of packets, delivered by this sub-layer to a higher (sub-)layer, which were not addressed to a multicast or broadcast address at this sub-layer. Discontinuities in the value of this counter can occur at re-initialization of the management system, and at other times as indicated by the value of ifCounterDiscontinuityTime.

in-broadcast-pkts.description: The number of packets, delivered by this sub-layer to a higher (sub-)layer, that were addressed to a broadcast address at this sub-layer. Discontinuities in the value of this counter can occur at re-initialization of the management system, and at other times as indicated by the value of 'last-clear'.

in-multicast-pkts.description: The number of packets, delivered by this sub-layer to a higher (sub-)layer, that were addressed to a multicast address at this sub-layer. For a MAC-layer protocol, this includes both Group and Functional addresses. Discontinuities in the value of this counter can occur at re-initialization of the management system, and at other times as indicated by the value of 'last-clear'.

in-discards.description: The number of inbound packets that were chosen to be discarded even though no errors had been detected to prevent their being deliverable to a higher-layer protocol. One possible reason for discarding such a packet could be to free up buffer space. Discontinuities in the value of this counter can occur at re-initialization of the management system, and at other times as indicated by the value of 'last-clear'

in-errors.description: For packet-oriented interfaces, the number of inbound packets that contained errors preventing them from being deliverable to a higher-layer protocol. For character- oriented or fixed-length interfaces, the number of inbound transmission units that contained errors preventing them from being deliverable to a higher-layer protocol. Discontinuities in the value of this counter can occur at re-initialization of the management system, and at other times as indicated by the value of 'last-clear'

in-fcs-errors.description: Number of received packets which had errors in the frame check sequence (FCS), i.e., framing errors. Discontinuities in the value of this counter can occur when the device is re-initialization as indicated by the value of 'last-clear'.

out-octets.description: The total number of octets transmitted out of the interface, including framing characters. Discontinuities in the value of this counter can occur at re-initialization of the management system, and at other times as indicated by the value of 'last-clear'.

out-pkts.description: The total number of packets transmitted out of the interface, including all unicast, multicast, broadcast, and bad packets etc.

out-unicast-pkts.description: The total number of packets that higher-level protocols requested be transmitted, and which were not addressed to a multicast or broadcast address at this sub-layer, including those that were discarded or not sent. Discontinuities in the value of this counter can occur at re-initialization of the management system, and at other times as indicated by the value of ifCounterDiscontinuityTime.

out-broadcast-pkts.description: The total number of packets that higher-level protocols requested be transmitted, and that were addressed to a broadcast address at this sub-layer, including those that were discarded or not sent. Discontinuities in the value of this counter can occur at re-initialization of the management system, and at other times as indicated by the value of 'last-clear'

out-multicast-pkts.description: The total number of packets that higher-level protocols requested be transmitted, and which were addressed to a multicast address at this sub-layer, including those that were discarded or not sent. For a MAC layer protocol, this includes both Group and Functional addresses. Discontinuities in the value of this counter can occur at re-initialization of the management system, and at other times as indicated by the value of ifCounterDiscontinuityTime.

out-discards.description: The number of outbound packets that were chosen to be discarded even though no errors had been detected to prevent their being transmitted. One possible reason for discarding such a packet could be to free up buffer space. Discontinuities in the value of this counter can occur at re-initialization of the management system, and at other times as indicated by the value of 'last-clear'.

out-errors.description: For packet-oriented interfaces, the number of outbound packets that could not be transmitted because of errors. For character-oriented or fixed-length interfaces, the number of outbound transmission units that could not be transmitted because of errors. Discontinuities in the value of this counter can occur at re-initialization of the management system, and at other times as indicated by the value of 'last-clear'.

last-clear.description: This Object describes the last counter clear

ipi-if-extended:extended-counters.description: A collection of extended interface-related statistics counters

in-errors.description: The number of discard segments received per LBG

out-segments.description: The number of Modem segments transmitted

out-segment-bytes.description: The number of Modem bytes transmitted

in-segments.description: The number of Modem Segments received

in-segment-bytes.description: The number of Modem bytes received

in-compressed.description: This Object describes Received compressed.This counter is only applicable to loopback (lo) and management interfaces like eth0

out-compressed.description: This Object describes Transmitted compressed.This counter is only applicable to loopback (lo) and management interfaces like eth0

collisions.description: This Object describes collisions.This counter is only applicable to loopback (lo) and management interfaces like eth0

unicast-rpf-discard.description: This Object describes unicast RPF discards.This counter is only applicable to loopback (lo) and management interfaces like eth0

in-length-errors.description: This Object describes Received Length Errors.This counter is only applicable to loopback (lo) and management interfaces like eth0

in-oversize-errors.description: This Object describes Received over Errors.This counter is only applicable to loopback (lo) and management interfaces like eth0

in-crc-errors.description: This Object describes Received CRC Errors.This counter is only applicable to loopback (lo) and management interfaces like eth0

in-frame-errors.description: This Object describes Received Frame Errors.This counter is only applicable to loopback (lo) and management interfaces like eth0

in-fifo-errors.description: This Object describes Received Fifo Errors.This counter is only applicable to loopback (lo) and management interfaces like eth0

in-missed-errors.description: This Object describes Received Missed Errors.This counter is only applicable to loopback (lo) and management interfaces like eth0

out-aborted-errors.description: This Object describes Transmitted Aborted Errors.This counter is only applicable to loopback (lo) and management interfaces like eth0

out-carrier-errors.description: This Object describes Transmitted Carrier Errors.This counter is only applicable to loopback (lo) and management interfaces like eth0

out-fifo-errors.description: This Object describes Transmitted Fifo Errors.This counter is only applicable to loopback (lo) and management interfaces like eth0

out-heartbeat-errors.description: This Object describes Transmitted Heart beat Errors.This counter is only applicable to loopback (lo) and management interfaces like eth0

out-window-errors.description: This Object describes Transmitted Window Errors.This counter is only applicable to loopback (lo) and management interfaces like eth0

l2-protocol-pkt-stat.description: This list is used to display statistics for L2 protocol control      packets

lacp-counters.description: This attribute specifies LACP Protocol Packets received on the interface

stp-counters.description: This attribute specifies stp protocol packets

lldp-counters.description: This attribute specifies lldp protocol Packets received on the interface

efmCounters.description: This attribute specifies efm protocol Packets received on the interface

elmi-counters.description: This attribute specifies elmi protocol Packets received on the interface

dot1x-counters.description: This attribute specifies dot1x protocol Packets received on the interface

synce-counters.description: This attribute specifies synce protocol Packets received on the interface

l2cp-counter-type.description: This attribute specifies the Protocol Packets received on the interface

error-disable-reason.description: This object specifies the event that caused the interface to be error-disabled. If interface is error-disabled because of lag-mismatch, value of this object is 1. If interface is error-disabled because of stp-bpdu-guard, value of this object is 2. If interface is error-disabled because of link-flap, value of this object is 4.

if-loopback.description: This attribute is used to enable port loopback

if-loopback-level.description: This attribute is used to enable port loopback

if-loopback.description: This attribute is used to enable port loopback

config.description: Configuration data for extended interface module

disable-multicast.description: This attribute is used to set multicast flag for the interface. For a MAC layer protocol, this includes both Group and Functional addresses. Multicast is enabled by default for L3 interfaces. Setting multicast flag for loopback and L2 subinterface is not allowed

link-flap-error-disable.description: This object specifies whether the interface is enabled for link-flap error-disable or not. If this is '0', then interface is not enabled. Otherwise it is enabled.

mac-move-limit-error-disable.description: This object specifies whether the interface is enabled for mac-move-limit error-disable or not. If this is '0', then interface is not enabled. Otherwise it is enabled.

disable-snmp-trap-link-status.description: This Object is used to set the snmp trap link status in an interface

mau-default-type.description: This attribute is used to set the mau type in an interface

debounce-time.description: Use this attribute to set the interface debounce timer value

protected-port.description: Attribute to change port protectedtype value

state.description: Counters/State data for extended interface module

disable-multicast.description: This attribute is used to set multicast flag for the interface. For a MAC layer protocol, this includes both Group and Functional addresses. Multicast is enabled by default for L3 interfaces. Setting multicast flag for loopback and L2 subinterface is not allowed

link-flap-error-disable.description: This object specifies whether the interface is enabled for link-flap error-disable or not. If this is '0', then interface is not enabled. Otherwise it is enabled.

mac-move-limit-error-disable.description: This object specifies whether the interface is enabled for mac-move-limit error-disable or not. If this is '0', then interface is not enabled. Otherwise it is enabled.

disable-snmp-trap-link-status.description: This Object is used to set the snmp trap link status in an interface

debounce-time.description: Use this attribute to set the interface debounce timer value

protected-port.description: Attribute to change port protectedtype value

properties.description: This attribute is used to display interface mapping properties

original-name.description: This Object is used to map the interface name

mapped-name.description: This Object is used to set interface mapped name

if-counter-discontinuity-time.description: The value of sysUpTime on the most recent occasion at which any one or more of this interface's counters suffered a discontinuity. The relevant counters are the specific instances associated with this interface of any Counter32 or Counter64 object contained in the ifTable or ifXTable. If no such discontinuities have occurred since the last re- initialization of the local management subsystem, then this object contains a zero value.

metric.description: This Object is used to check interface Metric

if-type.description: This Object describes the interface type L2, L3, TDM

trust-state.description: This Object describes the trust interface state

monitor-port-grp.description: This attribute describes Monitor Port Groups (MPG) interface

failover-link-type.description: This attribute describes trigger failover(TFO) link type

udld-flush-transmitted.description: This attribute describes interface udld Flush transmitted

debounce-flap-count.description: This attribute describes number of flap within debounce time interval

debounce-last-flap-time.description: This attribute describes the last debounce flap time

debounce-remain-time.description: This attribute describes the remaining debounce time interval

debounce-running-status.description: This attribute describes debounce time Running Status

debounce-config-status.description: This attribute describes whether debounce is configured or not

last-flapped.description: This Object describes time when the interface last flapped.

auto-ipv6-link-local-address.description: This Object describes the default link local IPv6 address assigned to the interface.

config.description: Configuration data for bandwidth-management

enable-re-routing.description: Enable re-routing when the bandwidth crosses down the minimum bandwidth

warning-threshold.description: This object is used to specify warning threshold for port speed monitor. Warning threshold must be greater than recovery threshold. Default value of warning-threshold is 90.

recovery-threshold.description: This object is used to specify recovery threshold for port speed monitor.Default value of recovery-threshold is 80.

src.description: This attribute is used to set tunnel source

dst.description: This attribute is used to set destination of tunnel packets

enable-untagged.description: Use this attribute to configure encapsulation as untagged

enable-untagged.description: Use this attribute to configure encapsulation as untagged

vlan-encapsulations.description: Loop back detection enables name configuration

config.description: This container defines LBD tagged configs

vlan-id.description: Use this attribute to create a single/range of VLANs on the VLAN aware bridges

state.description: Operational state data for system

vlan-id.description: Use this attribute to create a single/range of VLANs on the VLAN aware bridges

config.description: Configuration data for ethernet interfaces

duplex-mode.description: Use this attribute to set the duplex mode for the interface. Auto-negotiation if enabled, is turned off when duplex mode is set for the interface. When auto-negotiation is enabled, the interface should negotiate the duplex mode directly (typically full-duplex).

mac-address.description: Use this attribute to set the mac address for an interface. If not specified, the corresponding operational state leaf is expected to show the system-assigned MAC address.

secondary-mac-address.description: Use this attribute to set the secondary mac address for an interface to terminate L3 packets.

port-speed.description: This attribute is used to set the link speed for the interface. To enable auto-negotiation for the interface, set this attribute to value auto. When auto-negotiation is enabled, it is expected that the interface will select the highest speed available based on negotiation. When auto-negotiation is not enabled, sets the link speed to a fixed value -- supported values are defined by IF_INTERFACE_SPEED_T enum.

state.description: State variables for Ethernet interfaces

duplex-mode.description: Use this attribute to set the duplex mode for the interface. Auto-negotiation if enabled, is turned off when duplex mode is set for the interface. When auto-negotiation is enabled, the interface should negotiate the duplex mode directly (typically full-duplex).

mac-address.description: Use this attribute to set the mac address for an interface. If not specified, the corresponding operational state leaf is expected to show the system-assigned MAC address.

secondary-mac-address.description: Use this attribute to set the secondary mac address for an interface to terminate L3 packets.

port-speed.description: This attribute is used to set the link speed for the interface. To enable auto-negotiation for the interface, set this attribute to value auto. When auto-negotiation is enabled, it is expected that the interface will select the highest speed available based on negotiation. When auto-negotiation is not enabled, sets the link speed to a fixed value -- supported values are defined by IF_INTERFACE_SPEED_T enum.

hw-mac-address.description: Represenets the 'burned-in', or system-assigned, MAC address for the Ethernet interface.

negotiated-duplex-mode.description: When auto-negotiate is set to TRUE, and the interface has completed auto-negotiation with the remote peer, this value shows the duplex mode that has been negotiated.

negotiated-port-speed.description: When auto-negotiate is set to TRUE, and the interface has completed auto-negotiation with the remote peer, this value shows the speed that has been negotiated.

in-mac-control-frames.description: MAC layer control frames received on the interface

in-mac-pause-frames.description: MAC layer PAUSE frames received on the interface

in-undersize-frames.description: The total number of frames received that were less than 64 octets long (excluding framing bits, but including FCS octets) and were otherwisewell formed.

in-oversize-frames.description: The total number of frames received that were longer than 1518 octets (excluding framing bits, but including FCS octets) and were otherwise well formed.

in-fragment-frames.description: The total number of frames received that were less than 64 octets in length (excluding framing bits but including FCS octets) and had either a bad Frame Check Sequence (FCS) with an integral number of octets (FCS Error) or a bad FCS with a non-integral number of octets (Alignment Error).

in-jabber-frames.description: Number of jabber frames received on the interface. Jabber frames are typically defined as oversize frames which also have a bad CRC. Implementations may use slightly different definitions of what constitutes a jabber frame. Often indicative of a NIC hardware problem.

in-crc-errors.description: The total number of frames received that had a length (excluding framing bits, but including FCS octets) of between 64 and 1518 octets, inclusive, but had either a bad Frame Check Sequence (FCS) with an integral number of octets (FCS Error) or a bad FCS with a non-integral number of octets (Alignment Error)

out-mac-control-frames.description: MAC layer control frames sent on the interface

out-mac-pause-frames.description: MAC layer PAUSE frames sent on the interface

in-frames-64-octets.description: Number of packets (including bad packets) received that were 64 bytes in length (excluding framing bits but including FCS bytes).

in-frames-65-127-octets.description: Number of good and bad packets received that were between 65 and 127 bytes in length (excluding framing bits but including FCS bytes).

in-frames-128-255-octets.description: Number of good and bad packets received that were between 128 and 255 bytes in length inclusive (excluding framing bits but including FCS bytes).

in-frames-256-511-octets.description: Number of good and bad packets received that were between 256 and 511 bytes in length inclusive (excluding framing bits but including FCS bytes).

in-frames-512-1023-octets.description: Number of good and bad packets received that were between 512 and 1023 bytes in length inclusive (excluding framing bits but including FCS bytes).

in-frames-1024-1518-octets.description: Number of good and bad packets received that were between 1024 and 1518 bytes in length inclusive (excluding framing bits but including FCS bytes).

in-frames-1519-2047-octets.description: Number of good and bad packets received that were between 1519 and 2047 bytes in length inclusive (excluding framing bits but including FCS bytes).

in-frames-2048-4095-octets.description: Number of good and bad packets received that were between 2048 and 4095 bytes in length inclusive (excluding framing bits but including FCS bytes).

in-frames-4096-9216-octets.description: Number of good and bad packets received that were between 4096 and 9216 bytes in length inclusive (excluding framing bits but including FCS bytes).

in-frames-9217-16383-octets.description: Number of good and bad packets received that were between 9217 and 16383 bytes in length inclusive (excluding framing bits but including FCS bytes).

out-frames-64-octets.description: Number of packets (including bad packets) sent that were 64 bytes in length (excluding framing bits but including FCS bytes).

out-frames-65-127-octets.description: Number of good and bad packets sent that were between 65 and 127 bytes in length (excluding framing bits but including FCS bytes).

out-frames-128-255-octets.description: Number of good and bad packets sent that were between 128 and 255 bytes in length inclusive (excluding framing bits but including FCS bytes).

out-frames-256-511-octets.description: Number of good and bad packets sent that were between 256 and 511 bytes in length inclusive (excluding framing bits but including FCS bytes).

out-frames-512-1023-octets.description: Number of good and bad packets sent that were between 512 and 1023 bytes in length inclusive (excluding framing bits but including FCS bytes).

out-frames-1024-1518-octets.description: Number of good and bad packets sent that were between 1024 and 1518 bytes in length inclusive (excluding framing bits but including FCS bytes).

out-frames-1519-2047-octets.description: Number of good and bad packets sent that were between 1519 and 2047 bytes in length inclusive (excluding framing bits but including FCS bytes).

out-frames-2048-4095-octets.description: Number of good and bad packets sent that were between 2048 and 4095 bytes in length inclusive (excluding framing bits but including FCS bytes).

out-frames-4096-9216-octets.description: Number of good and bad packets sent that were between 4096 and 9216 bytes in length inclusive (excluding framing bits but including FCS bytes).

out-frames-9217-16383-octets.description: Number of good and bad packets sent that were between 9217 and 16383 bytes in length inclusive (excluding framing bits but including FCS bytes).

enable-rcv.description: This attribute is used to show flow control on receive

enable-snd.description: This attribute is used to show flow control on send

enable-snd.description: This attribute is used to show flow control on send

rcv-oper-status.description: This attribute is used to show Operations status of Flow control on receive

snd-oper-status.description: This attribute is used to show Operations status of Flow control on send

ipi-if-ip:ipv4.description: Parameters for the IPv4 address family

secondary-addresses.description: List of secondary IPv4 Addresses for the interface

ip-address.description: Use this attribute to specify a secondary IP address that will be used by this interface. The secondary address cannot be configured in the absence of a primary IP address. The primary address cannot be removed when a secondary address is present.

config.description: IPv4 secondary address configuration data for the interface

ip-address.description: Use this attribute to specify a secondary IP address that will be used by this interface. The secondary address cannot be configured in the absence of a primary IP address. The primary address cannot be removed when a secondary address is present.

ip-label.description: Use this attribute to specify a descriptive label for this IPv4 address.

secondary-anycast.description: Use this attribute to set the anycast flag for the IPv4 secondary address of an interface.

state.description: IPv4 secondary address list operational information

ip-address.description: Use this attribute to specify a secondary IP address that will be used by this interface. The secondary address cannot be configured in the absence of a primary IP address. The primary address cannot be removed when a secondary address is present.

ip-label.description: Use this attribute to specify a descriptive label for this IPv4 address.

secondary-anycast.description: Use this attribute to set the anycast flag for the IPv4 secondary address of an interface.

config.description: Top-level IPv4 configuration data for the interface

primary-ip-addr.description: Use this attribute to specify that an IP address and prefix length will be used by this interface. If the secondary parameter is not specified, this attribute overwrites the primary IP address. If the secondary parameter is specified, this attribute adds a new IP address to the interface. The secondary address cannot be configured in the absence of a primary IP address. The primary address cannot be removed when a secondary address is present.

enable-dhcp-ip-address.description: Use this attribute to specify that a DHCP client will be used to obtain an IP address for an interface.

prefix-length.description: The subnet mask associated with the IPv4 address of this entry. The value of the mask is an IPv4 address with all the network bits set to 1 and all the hosts bits set to 0.

ipv4-unnumbered-if-name.description: This attribute is used to Enable IP processing without an explicit address

remote-address.description: This attribute is used to set the remote address of the PPP link

primary-anycast.description: Use this attribute to set the anycast flag for the IPv4 primary address of an interface.

state.description: Top-level IPv4 operational state data for the interface

primary-ip-addr.description: Use this attribute to specify that an IP address and prefix length will be used by this interface. If the secondary parameter is not specified, this attribute overwrites the primary IP address. If the secondary parameter is specified, this attribute adds a new IP address to the interface. The secondary address cannot be configured in the absence of a primary IP address. The primary address cannot be removed when a secondary address is present.

enable-dhcp-ip-address.description: Use this attribute to specify that a DHCP client will be used to obtain an IP address for an interface.

prefix-length.description: The subnet mask associated with the IPv4 address of this entry. The value of the mask is an IPv4 address with all the network bits set to 1 and all the hosts bits set to 0.

ipv4-unnumbered-if-name.description: This attribute is used to Enable IP processing without an explicit address

remote-address.description: This attribute is used to set the remote address of the PPP link

primary-anycast.description: Use this attribute to set the anycast flag for the IPv4 primary address of an interface.

dhcp-ip-adddress.description: This attribute displays the IPv4 address allocated by DHCP

ipv4-enabled-status.description: This attribute displays IPv4 enable status

ipi-if-ip:ipv6.description: Parameters for the IPv6 address family

addresses.description: List of IPv6 Addresses for the interface

ipv6-address.description: Use this attribute to set the IPv6 address of an interface

config.description: IPv6 address configuration data for the interface

ipv6-address.description: Use this attribute to set the IPv6 address of an interface

anycast.description: Use this attribute to set the anycast flag for the IPv6 address of an interface. Anycast flag cannot be deleted for an IPv6 address once set. Please delete IPv6 address and reconfigure to remove anycast property.

state.description: IPv6 address list operational data for the interface

ipv6-address.description: Use this attribute to set the IPv6 address of an interface

anycast.description: Use this attribute to set the anycast flag for the IPv6 address of an interface. Anycast flag cannot be deleted for an IPv6 address once set. Please delete IPv6 address and reconfigure to remove anycast property.

config.description: Top-level IPv6 configuration data for the interface

ipv6-unnumbered-if-name.description: Use this attribute to enable IP processing without an explicit address

enable-dhcp-ipv6-address.description: Use this attribute to specify that a DHCP client will be used to obtain an IP address for an interface.

enable-dhcp-temporary-ipv6-address.description: Use this attribute to specify that a DHCP client will be used to obtain an temporary IP address for an interface.

dhcp-address-prefix-length.description: Use this attribute to configure the prefix length for the dynamically learnt ipv6 address

enable-auto-config.description: Use this attribute to enable autoconfiguration of IPv6 address in host interface. IPv6 address are formed using the Prefix learned from RA and suffix formed using EUI-64 method.

state.description: Top-level IPv6 operational state data for the interface

ipv6-unnumbered-if-name.description: Use this attribute to enable IP processing without an explicit address

enable-dhcp-ipv6-address.description: Use this attribute to specify that a DHCP client will be used to obtain an IP address for an interface.

enable-dhcp-temporary-ipv6-address.description: Use this attribute to specify that a DHCP client will be used to obtain an temporary IP address for an interface.

dhcp-address-prefix-length.description: Use this attribute to configure the prefix length for the dynamically learnt ipv6 address

enable-auto-config.description: Use this attribute to enable autoconfiguration of IPv6 address in host interface. IPv6 address are formed using the Prefix learned from RA and suffix formed using EUI-64 method.

dhcp-ipv6-adddress.description: This attribute is used to describes DHCP IPv6 Address

forwarding-status.description: This attribute describes the IPv6 Forwarding status

auto-addresses.description: Parameters for the Learnt IPv6 address from Peer

auto-address.description: List of Learnt IPv6 address from Peer

ipv6-address.description: Use this attribute to get the Auto IPv6 address of an interface

anycast.description: Use this attribute to get the anycast flag for the Auto IPv6 address of an interface.

virtual.description: Use this attribute to get the virtual flag for the Auto IPv6 address of an interface.

vrrp.description: Use this attribute to get the vrrp flag for the Auto IPv6 address of an interface.

agg-type.description: Sets the type of LAG, how it is configured / maintained

lacp-mode.description: Use this command to add a port to a channel group specified by the channel group number (1-12). This command enables link aggregation on a port, so that it may be selected for aggregation by the local system.

interface-mode.description: Set the interface to access or trunk or hybrid mode for VLANs

ingress-filter.description: Use this attribute to set the switching characteristics of the interface as hybrid, and classify both tagged and untagged frames. Received frames are classified based on the VLAN characteristics, then accepted or discarded based on the specified filtering criteria.

acceptable-frame-type.description: Use this attribute to set the interface acceptable frame types. This processing occurs after VLAN classification

disable-native-vlan.description: Use this attribute to disable native VLAN for the port. Untagged frames will be dropped.

remove-default-vlan.description: Use this attribute to remove default VLAN for the port. Untagged frames will be dropped.

acceptable-frame-type.description: Use this attribute to set the interface acceptable frame types. This processing occurs after VLAN classification

disable-native-vlan.description: Use this attribute to disable native VLAN for the port. Untagged frames will be dropped.

remove-default-vlan.description: Use this attribute to remove default VLAN for the port. Untagged frames will be dropped.

config.description: Global error-disable configuration parameters for the router

reason.description: This object is to enable various error-disable reasons like lag-mismatch, stp-bpdu-guard, link-flap and loopback-detection. As the datatype is BITS, 0th bit corresponds to lag-mismatch, 1st bit corresponds to stp-bpdu-guard, 2nd bit corresponds to link-flap

error-disable-stp-bpdu-guard.description: This object is used to configure error disable STP BPDU Guard

timeout-interval.description: This object is to configure timeout for error-disable automatic recovery timer

link-flap-max-count.description: This object is to configure allowed flap count to detect link-flap error-disable

link-flap-timer-interval.description: This object is configure timer interval for link-flap timer

mac-move-limit.description: This object configures threshold for mac movement
